Message.Title: Best Chinese carry-out, boys : Over 2,000,000 Genuine iPhone 5's sold in first 3 days.
Message.Msg: iPhone 5 First Weekend Sales in China Top Two Million BEIJING--(BUSINESS WIRE) -- "Apple® today announced it has sold over two million of its new iPhone® 5 in China, just three days after its launch on December 14. iPhone 5 will be available in more than 100 countries by the end of December, making it the Fastest iPhone rollout ever. "Customer response to iPhone 5 in China has been incredible, setting a new record with the best first weekend sales ever in China," said Tim Cook, Apple's CEO. "China is a very important market for us and customers there cannot wait to get their hands on Apple products." iPhone 5 is the thinnest and lightest iPhone ever, completely redesigned to feature a stunning new 4-inch Retina® display; an Apple-designed A6 chip for blazing fast performance; and ultrafast wireless technology*—all while delivering even better battery life. iPhone 5 comes with iOS 6, the world's most advanced mobile operating system with over 200 new features including: Shared Photo Streams, all-new Maps app, Passbook® organization and even more Siri® features and languages including Mandarin. Apple designs Macs, the best personal computers in the world, along with OS X, iLife, iWork and professional software. Apple leads the digital music revolution with its iPods and iTunes online store. Apple has reinvented the mobile phone with its revolutionary iPhone and App Store, and is defining the future of mobile media and computing devices with iPad." "Customer response to iPhone 5 in China has been INCREDIBLE, setting a New Record with the BEST First Weekend Sales Ever in China," said Tim Cook, Apple's CEO. Looks like sales of those android devices in China are going to, well, dim sum.

Topic.Title: Intel rumored to be buying NVDA

Message.Msg: Never believe any rumors - I think out of all the PC centric companies the one more likely to benefit from NVIDIA and visa-versa is MFST. That would give them an entire product pipeline in which the could leverage their consumer (gaming, mobile) as well as enterprise (servers, etc), and compete with apple by owning all the IP and products up and down the chain. Not to mention the advantage of moving the xbox gaming titles to the cloud via NVIDIA's technology. Just my .02 cents.

Topic.Title: Intel rumored to be buying NVDA

Message.Msg: Umm.....people like the OP are usually trying to start rumors, not repeating them.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA "Grey" processor has been upgraded to Wayne + i500 LTE

Message.Msg: Hi Ibexx. I am not sure you are correct. The slide indicates they are selling Wayne + LTE. But in the conference call (or just conference) they talk about selling SOC chip and LTE as discrete solutions. One analyst has a specific question about this. So I am just saying I dont think the slide support a clear conclusion on the matter. /Frank.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA "Grey" processor has been upgraded to Wayne + i500 LTE

Message.Msg: It could just mean selling them as discrete items.

Message.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5
Message.Msg: The Apple A6 processor costs $17.50. The LTE Qualcomm base band costs $25.00. This has not been well known. Icera purchase may turn out as a steal. Say 50% of Tegra 4 sales generate a I500 base band sales. That is a huge plus!

Topic.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5

Message.Msg: "The Apple A6 processor costs $17.50" It's a good thing that Apple doesn't sell their superb Apple A6 processor to the public. Yet. 'Cause if they did, nvidia's sub-par and over-priced tegra would be out of business. Yes boys, Out-of-Business. But there HAVE been rumors from time-to-time. Nasty, horrible, scary rumors. Oh so scary. That Apple might someday change their policy -- and sell their A-series chips to others. Maybe when they get the entire iPhone integrated on one piece of silicon. And Apple makes 'em themselves in their own New York fab plant. "$17.50 for the entire cellphone System-on-a-Chip. Plus $200 bucks for the (zero-cost to Apple) iOS operating system." Now THERE'S what a highly iProfitable Business Model looks like, boys. To an industry Desperate for a really good, non-patent infringing operating system. It would be transformational, right? It sure will be.

Topic.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5

Message.Msg: "Apple does what Apple does and nobody else is going to compete with them." -- Current nvidia CEO Jen Hsun Huang, MobileBeat, March 4, 2011.

Topic.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5

Message.Msg: So Best? If Apple supplies Everything that a copy-cat would need to make a licensed knock-off of the Genuine iPhone -- what happens to the carrier's customary $450 per iPhone payment? Apple splits it with the copy cat? $225 each. Nice money for Apple -- for selling one chip and a zero cost operating system. $17.50 + $200.00 + $225.00 = $442.50 REALLY nice money. She's lookin' more like a Thousand Dollar ($1,000.00) stock every day, boys. Just like Goldman said.

Topic.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5

Message.Msg: What's the cause of your psychotic obsession with nvda? Was reading some posts... some claim that you lost your life's savings on a stock called rmbs.... somehow nvda crushed rmbs in a lawsuit .. and you still can't get over it... is this true?

Topic.Title: Interesting fact About BOM Cost of Iphone 5

Message.Msg: So Master? The licensed copy-cat people making those Apple iPhone knock-offs. Could they send their customers to the 500+ conveniently located Genuine Apple Stores for service on their knock-off devices? Like to set-up apps or fix a cracked screen or get a new charger or this and that. It would make sense, right? They would use the exact same parts as Apple uses. "Genuine Apple parts -- accept no substitutes." Okay, so maybe Apple charges the licensed copy-cat people $50 bucks per year per device for their superb Apple expert service. It's still easier than the copy-cat people trying to do it themselves. $17.50 + $200.00 + $225.00 + $50.00 = $492.50 Did I mention? REALLY nice money for Apple, boys.
